elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Two novel polyoxometalate (POM)-based organic–inorganic hybrids, namely, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Co(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Ni(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-([4,2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]-4′-yl)benzoic acid), have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, TG analyses and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isostructural and feature microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions. Topologically, the overall structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be classified as a rare (3,5)-connected twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net, which has never been observed in POM-based hybrid materials prior to this work. Furthermore, the magnetic property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are discussed.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Two novel polyoxometalate (POM)-based organic–inorganic hybrids, namely, [(CH3)2NH2][Co(tpba)(Mo2O7)]·2H2O (1) and [(CH3)2NH2][Ni(tpba)(Mo2O7)]·2H2O (2) (tpba=4-([4,2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]-4′-yl)benzoic acid), have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, TG analyses and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural and feature microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions. Topologically, the overall structures of 1 and 2 can be classified as a rare (3,5)-connected twofold interpenetrated hms net, which has never been observed in POM-based hybrid materials prior to this work. Furthermore, the magnetic property of compound 1 are discussed.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st0010">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0040" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit 3D microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:alt-text id="al0035" role="short">Image 1</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0035" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S1387700316301253/fx1" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0045" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Microporous interpenetrated frameworks based on polyoxometalates.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">3D nets constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit 3D microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions.

Image 1




Highlights



•
Microporous interpenetrated frameworks based on polyoxometalates.


•
3D nets constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions.


•
The first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated hms net.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:alt-text id="al0035" role="short">Image 1</ce:alt-text>
<ce:link id="lk0035" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S1387700316301253/fx1" xlink:type="simple"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Image 1

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Microporous interpenetrated frameworks based on polyoxometalates.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">3D nets constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Entangled systems have captured great interest and developed rapidly in recent years owing to their intrinsic aesthetic characters and their wide range of potential applications as functional solid state materials for gas storage, separation, microelectronics, nonlinear optics, ion exchange and catalysis . Interpenetrating nets, as the most explored and widespread type of entanglement, have provided a longstanding fascination for chemists. A remarkable feature of interpenetration is that the individual motifs could not be separated except for breaking internal connections . Polyoxometalates (POMs), as an outstanding class of metal<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>oxide clusters, has aroused enormous interest among chemists in many fields of catalysis, magnetism, biological activity and optics . During the past few decades, more and more attention has been paid to the rational design of new POM-based organic–inorganic hybrids due to their considerable structural versatility related with their controllable shapes and sizes, highly negative charges, and oxo-enriched surfaces . However, compared with the successful synthesis of other MOF-modified POMs, the interpenetrating networks based on POMs are rarely explored, especially for the 3D microporous frameworks . On the other hand, the pillared-layer structures have attracted long-lasting interest due to such excellent merits as controlling the cavity size and the chemical functionality <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> modification of the pillar module . Moreover, compared with the POM-based organic–inorganic hybrids pillared by organic ligands, organic–inorganic hybrids with POM anions as pillars are rarely explored, especially for hybrids featuring interpenetrated frameworks . Hence, it is still a current challenge to synthesize microporous interpenetrated frameworks composed of metal–organic layers pillared by the POMs, and further research is necessary to enrich and develop this branch.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Microporous interpenetrated frameworks based on polyoxometalates.
3D nets constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions.
The first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated hms net.
Entangled systems have captured great interest and developed rapidly in recent years owing to their intrinsic aesthetic characters and their wide range of potential applications as functional solid state materials for gas storage, separation, microelectronics, nonlinear optics, ion exchange and catalysis . Interpenetrating nets, as the most explored and widespread type of entanglement, have provided a longstanding fascination for chemists. A remarkable feature of interpenetration is that the individual motifs could not be separated except for breaking internal connections . Polyoxometalates (POMs), as an outstanding class of metal−oxide clusters, has aroused enormous interest among chemists in many fields of catalysis, magnetism, biological activity and optics . During the past few decades, more and more attention has been paid to the rational design of new POM-based organic–inorganic hybrids due to their considerable structural versatility related with their controllable shapes and sizes, highly negative charges, and oxo-enriched surfaces . However, compared with the successful synthesis of other MOF-modified POMs, the interpenetrating networks based on POMs are rarely explored, especially for the 3D microporous frameworks . On the other hand, the pillared-layer structures have attracted long-lasting interest due to such excellent merits as controlling the cavity size and the chemical functionality via modification of the pillar module . Moreover, compared with the POM-based organic–inorganic hybrids pillared by organic ligands, organic–inorganic hybrids with POM anions as pillars are rarely explored, especially for hybrids featuring interpenetrated frameworks . Hence, it is still a current challenge to synthesize microporous interpenetrated frameworks composed of metal–organic layers pillared by the POMs, and further research is necessary to enrich and develop this branch.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">With the above stated aspects in mind, we purposely focused our attention on a rigid ligand, 4-([4,2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]- 4′-yl)benzoic acid (tpba), based on the following considerations: (i) Take the advantages of a rigid backbone and a directional extending ability, which are beneficial for building up microporous framework. (ii) It has many potential coordination modes, allowing for the construction of topologically diverse coordination network. In addition, the small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion can be obtained from [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> under alkaline conditions. The integration of small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion and large-sized tpba ligand, which could surmount the steric hindrance of POMs in self-assembling processes, makes it possible to acquire POM-based microporous interpenetrated frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With the above stated aspects in mind, we purposely focused our attention on a rigid ligand, 4-([4,2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]- 4′-yl)benzoic acid (tpba), based on the following considerations: (i) Take the advantages of a rigid backbone and a directional extending ability, which are beneficial for building up microporous framework. (ii) It has many potential coordination modes, allowing for the construction of topologically diverse coordination network. In addition, the small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion can be obtained from [Mo7O24]2− under alkaline conditions. The integration of small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion and large-sized tpba ligand, which could surmount the steric hindrance of POMs in self-assembling processes, makes it possible to acquire POM-based microporous interpenetrated frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In the present work, we report the syntheses and characteristics of two microporous interpenetrated frameworks, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Co(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][Ni(tpba)(Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-([4.2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]-4′-yl)benzoic acid), which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions. Topologically, the overall structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be simplified as a (3,5)-connected twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net with the point symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.8) . The crystal structure, topological analysis and magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be represented and discussed in this paper.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the present work, we report the syntheses and characteristics of two microporous interpenetrated frameworks, [(CH3)2NH2][Co(tpba)(Mo2O7)]·2H2O (1) and [(CH3)2NH2][Ni(tpba)(Mo2O7)]·2H2O (2) (tpba=4-([4.2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]-4′-yl)benzoic acid), which are constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions. Topologically, the overall structures of 1 and 2 can be simplified as a (3,5)-connected twofold interpenetrated hms net with the point symbol of (63)(69.8) . The crystal structure, topological analysis and magnetic property of 1 will be represented and discussed in this paper.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">X-ray crystallography shows that compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are isostructural, since they crystallize in the same space group with almost identical cell parameters . Therefore, only the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> will be discussed in detail. Purple block crystal of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was synthesized by heating a mixture of CoSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, Htpba, (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, DMF and distilled water at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . It was further characterized by elemental analyses, power X-ray diffraction (Figs. S3–4), TG analysis (Figs. S5–6) and IR spectrum (Figs. S7–8). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in monoclinic system with space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>. There are a half Co(II) ion, a half [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion and a half Htpba ligand in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). Based on charge balance consideration and bond valence sum calculations , the Co atom exhibits the +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>II oxidation state and the Mo atom exhibits the +<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>VI oxidation state. The Co atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two Htpba ligands (Co-N 2.142(2) Å), two carboxylate oxygen atoms from one Htpba ligand and two oxygen atoms from two different [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions (Co-O 2.0719(18)–2.1984(18) Å) to form a distorted octahedron coordination. While the Mo atom exhibits a distorted tetrahedral geometry, coordinated by two terminal oxygen atoms and two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging oxygen atoms [Mo-O 1.716(2)–1.8774(5) Å]. The tetradentate tpba ligand in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> link three Co atoms. In detail, the carboxylate group chelates with one Co(II) ion, and the two pyridine groups adopt a monodentate coordination mode connecting two Co(II) ions (Scheme S1). The [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions link two Co(II) ions as the pillar.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Based on the above connection modes, the Co ions are connected by tpba ligands to form a 2D metal–organic layer. Topologically, the 2D metal–organic layer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a 3-connected 6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>-<ce:bold>hcb</ce:bold> net (a and b<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Interestingly, these 2D metal–organic layers are further pillared by [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions to generate a (3,5)-connected 3D <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net with the point symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">9</ce:sup>.8), in which the tpba ligand and Co atom are respectively simplified as 3- and 5-connected nodes (c and d). Noteworthy, a single 3D network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses open 1D channels along the [0 0 1] (<ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 9.001<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>13.947<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), and [1 0 0] directions (<ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 9.446<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>16.773<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). Worth mentioning here is that the channels along the [0 0 1] direction are enclosed by the helical chains formed by [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions and 4-(2-(pyridin-4-yl)pyr-idin-4-yl)benzoate groups of tpba ligands bridging the Co atoms (). More intriguingly, a careful examination shows that all the helices in the same individual 3D network exhibit the same chirality (). Moreover, the single 3D network has the large voids to allow the incorporation of another identical 3D network, thus giving a rare twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). To our knowledge, the interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net has never been observed in POM-based hybrid materials prior to this work. An analysis of the interpenetration topology with the TOPOS program  reveals that it belongs to class IIa (two interpenetrated nets are generated only by a full interpenetration symmetry element (inversion center) and the non-translational degree Z<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2). Despite the interpenetration, PLATON analysis showed that the effective free volume of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 16.8% of the crystal volume, which is occupied by guest water molecules and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations . To the best of our knowledge, such a 3D microporous interpenetrated framework constructed from metal–organic layers pillared by the polyoxomolybdate anions is still uncommon within POM-based organic–inorganic hybrids .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated over the temperature range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at an applied field of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). At 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value of 4.402<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (5.934 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) is much higher than the spin-only value of 1.875<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (3.873 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) expected for one isolated Co(II) ions (S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.0) (a), which can be ascribed to the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment of Co(II) centers . Upon cooling, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value decreases monotonically and reaches a value of 2.043<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which can be attributed to spin-orbit coupling and/or crystal field effect and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS) . The Curie-Weiss fitting of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> in the temperature range of 36–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K gives a good result with C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>47.289<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The magnetic property of 1 was investigated over the temperature range of 2–300K at an applied field of 1kOe (
). At 300K, the χ
M
T value of 4.402cm3
Kmol−1 (5.934 μB) is much higher than the spin-only value of 1.875cm3
Kmol−1 (3.873 μB) expected for one isolated Co(II) ions (S=3/2, g=2.0) (a), which can be ascribed to the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment of Co(II) centers . Upon cooling, the χ
M
T value decreases monotonically and reaches a value of 2.043cm3
K at 2K, which can be attributed to spin-orbit coupling and/or crystal field effect and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS) . The Curie-Weiss fitting of 1/χ
M in the temperature range of 36–300K gives a good result with C=4.460cm3
Kmol−1 and θ
=−47.289K.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In conclusion, two POM-based organic-inorganic hybrids featuring microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are built up from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions, were synthesized. The successful isolation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> not only provides the first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net, but also indicates that the integration of small-sized POM anions and large-sized ligands may be a promising strategy for the construction of POM-based interpenetrated frameworks, thus opening a new avenue in the exploration of multifunctional POM-based entangled frameworks.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, two POM-based organic-inorganic hybrids featuring microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are built up from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo2O7]2− anions, were synthesized. The successful isolation of compounds 1 and 2 not only provides the first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated hms net, but also indicates that the integration of small-sized POM anions and large-sized ligands may be a promising strategy for the construction of POM-based interpenetrated frameworks, thus opening a new avenue in the exploration of multifunctional POM-based entangled frameworks.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st0035">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">CCDC reference numbers 1444647–1444648 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. Some additional structural figures and tables, PXRD patterns, TG-DSC curves, IR spectrum, and additional details for single-crystal structural refinements can be found in the supporting file. Supplementary materials associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi: <ce:inter-ref id="ir0005" xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2016.04.028" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2016.04.028</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para>

elements.content: <ce:simple-para id="sp0080" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: The mixture of CoSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Ni(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Htpba (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), distilled water (9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and DMF (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were stirred about 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air, then transferred and sealed in a 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which were heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, purple block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and green block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained, washed with distilled water several times, and dried at ambient temperature. We speculate that the DMF and/or (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH may act as bases during the preparation procedures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, yield: 51% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>CoMo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 36.15; H, 3.29; Co, 7.39; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03%. Found: C, 36.24; H, 3.21; Co, 7.35; Mo, 24.12; N, 7.09%. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, yield: 55% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>NiMo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 36.17; H, 3.29; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03; Ni, 7.36%. Found: C, 36.22; H, 3.25; Mo, 24.11; N, 7.12; Ni, 7.31%.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1 and 2: The mixture of CoSO4·7H2O (0.2mmol) or Ni(Ac)2·4H2O (0.2mmol), Htpba (0.2mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (0.2mmol), distilled water (9mL) and DMF (1ml) were stirred about 15min in air, then transferred and sealed in a 17mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which were heated at 160°C for 96h under autogenous pressure. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10°C/h, purple block crystals of 1 and green block crystals of 2 were obtained, washed with distilled water several times, and dried at ambient temperature. We speculate that the DMF and/or (CH3)2NH may act as bases during the preparation procedures of 1 and 2. For compound 1, yield: 51% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C24H26CoMo2N4O11: C, 36.15; H, 3.29; Co, 7.39; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03%. Found: C, 36.24; H, 3.21; Co, 7.35; Mo, 24.12; N, 7.09%. For compound 2, yield: 55% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C24H26NiMo2N4O11: C, 36.17; H, 3.29; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03; Ni, 7.36%. Found: C, 36.22; H, 3.25; Mo, 24.11; N, 7.12; Ni, 7.31%.

metadata.title: Two novel molybdenum-oxide-based organic-inorganic hybrid frameworks exhibiting twofold interpenetrated hms networks
